title: 108_hr3435
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission on Employment and Economic Security Act". It includes findings related to employment and economic security. The findings in the curr_chunk highlight the importance of employment for individuals and the economy, noting the high unemployment rates among certain demographics like minorities. The loss of a job can lead to depression due to the subsequent loss of income. The "National Commission on Employment and Economic Security" is established to address high unemployment rates among certain demographics and the impact of job loss on individuals and the economy. The Commission is tasked with examining economic and psychological insecurity in the US workforce due to employment displacement, stress, and lack of well-paid jobs. It will also recommend solutions through legislative and administrative actions. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate leaders. Appointments include individuals representing labor organizations, business interests, and mental health interests. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by officials, including the President and Senate leaders. Members must be experts in labor and employment, appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment for life. Vacancies filled as original appointments. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by officials, including the President and Senate leaders. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. 8 members constitute a quorum for the Commission, with the Chairperson elected by members within 30 days or appointed by the President if necessary. Meetings are held at the Chairperson's call. The Chairperson appoints Commission staff, who are subject to certain civil service laws. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and obtain necessary information from federal agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can use the United States mails like other federal agencies. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and evidence production, and it is granted immunity under the United States Code. Administrative support services are provided by the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel testimony and evidence production. If a person refuses to obey a subpoena, the Commission can seek a court order for compliance. Subpoenas are served in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The Commission also has the authority to contract with others. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies or persons for supplies or services, without following certain procurement regulations. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within a year of all members being appointed, detailing findings and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2004 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended.
